elements.content: The reaction of di-n-butyltin oxide with 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid tetrahydrate in a 2:1 ratio afforded [{n-Bu2Sn(μ-OH)}2{μ-1,5-C10H6(SO3)2}] n (1). The latter is a three-dimensional coordination polymer, in a honeycomb architecture, containing [Sn2(μ-OH)2] repeat units that are connected to each other by the bridging coordination action of the disulfonate ligand. Reaction of [n-R2SnO] n (R = n-Bu or Ph) with 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid tetrahydrate in a 1:1 ratio followed by reaction with bifunctional N-oxide ligands (4,4′-bipyridine-N,N′-dioxide (BPDO-II), 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane-N,N′-dioxide (BPDO-III), or P-oxide (1,2-bis(diphenylphosphoryl)ethane (DPPOE)) ligands afforded, depending on the stoichiometry/reaction conditions, various compounds: [{n-Bu2Sn(BPDO-II)2(H2O)2}{1,5-C10H6(SO3)2}] (2); [n-Bu2Sn(μ-BPDO-II)(μ-1,5-C10H6(SO3)2)] n (3); [n-Bu2Sn(μ-DPPOE)(μ-1,5-C10H6(SO3)2)] n (4); [{Ph2Sn(μ-BPDO-II)(H2O)2}{1,5-C10H6(SO3)2}·2H2O] n (5·2H 2 O); [{n-Bu2Sn(μ-BPDO-III)2}{1,5-C10H6(SO3)2}·5H2O] n (6·5H 2 O); [{n-Bu2Sn(BPDO-III-H)2}{μ-1,5-C10H6(SO3)2}{1,5-C10H6(SO3)2}] n (7); and [{n-Bu2Sn(DPPOE)2}{μ-1,5-C10H6(SO3)2}2{n-Bu2Sn(CH3OH)(μ-OH)}2·2H2O] n (8·2H 2 O). On the other hand, the reaction of [n-Bu2SnO] n with 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid tetrahydrate in a 2:1 ratio followed by nicotinic acid N-oxide multifunctional ligand (NO-IV) afforded [(n-Bu2Sn)(μ-1,5-C5H4(NO)(COO))2(μ-1,5-C10H6(SO3)2)(n-Bu2Sn)(H2O)(CH3OH)·CH3OH] n (9·CH 3 OH) and [(Bu2Sn)(H2O)(μ-1,5-C5H4)(NO)(COO))(μ-1,5-C10H6(SO3)2)1/2] n (10). While 2 is a molecular compound, 3 is a coordination polymer containing both sulfonate and N-oxide bridges. 4 is isostructrual with 3 except that the ligand involved is a bifunctional P-oxide ligand. 5 also is a coordination polymer, although, in this case, only the N-oxide ligands are in the coordination sphere of tin. 6 is a coordination polymer containing interlinked 28-membered macrocycles which are formed as a result of the flexible nature of the BPDO-III ligand. In contrast, in 7 one end of the BPDO-III ligand is protonated and hence does not take any part in coordination to tin. In this case, the coordination polymer is formed by the exclusive coordination action of the disulfonate ligand. Compound 8 reveals it to be a coordination polymer containing alternately [Sn2(μ-OH)2] and a discrete tin unit that are connected by disulfonate ligands. The coordination polymers 9 and 10 are obtained by a variation of crystallization conditions in the three-component reactions using NO-IV as the bridging ligand. While 9 is a neutral porous 2D-coordination polymer consisting of two different types of interconnected diorganotin units, 10 is a nonporous 2D-framework containing only one type of diorganotin unit. Most of the compounds prepared in this study showed good thermal stability, as indicated by their thermogravimetric analyses.

Compound 8 reveals it to be a coordination polymer containing alternately [Sn2(μ-OH)2] and a discrete tin unit that are connected by disulfonate ligands. The coordination polymers 9 and 10 are obtained by a variation of crystallization conditions in the three-component reactions using NO-IV as the bridging ligand. Most of the compounds prepared in this study showed good thermal stability, as indicated by their thermogravimetric analyses.

elements.content: Coordination-driven self-assembly reactions have become powerful tools to prepare designer compounds possessing various architectures. Both discrete molecules and solids possessing extended structures have become accessible through this route. Starting initially as a curiosity-driven exercise, this powerful synthetic methodology is now being increasingly viewed as a reliable method for the preparation of functional materials. Applications of some such functional materials include electrical conductivity, catalysis, magnetism, host−guest chemistry, and use as nanosized reaction containers, anion exchange materials, and so on. The basic components involved in this methodology are the use of metal ions or metal complexes as nodes/connectors which are linked to each other by di-/polyfunctional organic/metalloorganic ligands. In spite of the large potential and success of this methodology, surprisingly, its synthetic application has been limited to the use of mainly transition metal ions/complexes as nodes, although a few examples of main-group containing compounds are now known. One of the principal challenges in this endeavor appears to be the design of main-group metal-containing motifs that contain ligands which are labile and which are also positioned appropriately around the metal ion so that their replacement with bridging ligands would afford supramolecular coordination assemblies. In this context, we found it useful to examine the applicability of organotin compounds for framework assemblies. The family of organotin compounds in general and organooxotin compounds in particular are well-known for their structural diversity. It has also been shown that some of the Sn−O based clusters serve as supports for anchoring electroactive, photoactive, and coordinating groups around the periphery. Recently the utilization of dicarboxylate ligands in organotin chemistry has yielded rich dividends. Various types of extended structures, including those that possess 3D-porous structures, have been isolated. Similarly, the reactions of transition metal cyanide complexes with organotin halides have afforded complexes of the type [(R n Sn) x [M(CN) m ] y , which are framework solids that exhibit diverse topologies and possess varied applications.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination-driven self-assembly reactions have become powerful tools to prepare designer compounds possessing various architectures. Both discrete molecules and solids possessing extended structures have become accessible through this route. Starting initially as a curiosity-driven exercise, this powerful synthetic methodology is now being increasingly viewed as a reliable method for the preparation of functional materials. Applications of some such functional materials include electrical conductivity, catalysis, magnetism, host-guest chemistry, and use as nanosized reaction containers, anion exchange materials, and so on. The basic components involved in this methodology are the use of metal ions or metal complexes as nodes/connectors which are linked to each other by di-/polyfunctional organic/metalloorganic ligands. In spite of the large potential and success of this methodology, surprisingly, its synthetic application has been limited to the use of mainly transition metal ions/complexes as nodes, although a few examples of main-group containing compounds are now known. One of the principal challenges in this endeavor appears to be the design of main-group metal-containing motifs that contain ligands which are labile and which are also positioned appropriately around the metal ion so that their replacement with bridging ligands would afford supramolecular coordination assemblies. In this context, we found it useful to examine the applicability of organotin compounds for framework assemblies. The family of organotin compounds in general and organooxotin compounds in particular are well-known for their structural diversity. It has also been shown that some of the Sn-O based clusters serve as supports for anchoring electroactive, photoactive, and coordinating groups around the periphery. Recently the utilization of dicarboxylate ligands in organotin chemistry has yielded rich dividends. Various types of extended structures, including those that possess 3D-porous structures, have been isolated. Similarly, the reactions of transition metal cyanide complexes with organotin halides have afforded complexes of the type [(R n Sn) x [M(CN) m ] y , which are framework solids that exhibit diverse topologies and possess varied applications.

elements.content: We reported a few years ago, that a 1:2 reaction of [n-Bu2SnO] n with 2,5-xylyl sulfonic acid leads to the formation of [n-Bu2Sn(H2O)4][2,5-Me2-C6H3SO3]2. We attempted to use this compound as a precursor to obtain molecular squares, rectangles, and coordination frameworks by the replacement of its coordinated water molecules with bifunctional nitrogen ligands. Although treatment of this cation with chelating 1,10-phenanthroline afforded [n-Bu2Sn(Phen)(H2O)(2,5-Me2-C6H3SO3)][2,5-Me2-C6H3SO3], reactions with various bifunctional nitrogen ligands such as 4,4′-bipyridine or pyrazine did not afford the substitution of the aquo ligands but resulted in their deprotonation, leading to hydroxide-bridged compounds. To overcome this problem, we decided to use various bifunctional N-oxides (BPDO-II and BPDO-III), P-oxides (DPPOE), and mixed ligands (NO-IV) (Chart ).

We attempted to use this compound as a precursor to obtain molecular squares, rectangles, and coordination frameworks by the replacement of its coordinated water molecules with bifunctional nitrogen ligands. Although treatment of this cation with chelating 1,10-phenanthroline afforded [n-Bu2Sn(Phen)(H2O)(2,5-Me2-C6H3SO3)][2,5-Me2-C6H3SO3], reactions with various bifunctional nitrogen ligands such as 4,4'-bipyridine or pyrazine did not afford the substitution of the aquo ligands but resulted in their deprotonation, leading to hydroxide-bridged compounds. To overcome this problem, we decided to use various bifunctional N-oxides (BPDO-II and BPDO-III), P-oxides (DPPOE), and mixed ligands (NO-IV) (Chart ).

Accordingly, in this paper we report three-component reactions involving organotin oxides/disulfonic acids/N-oxides or P-oxides. Depending on the type of N-oxide or P-oxide ligand as well as the reaction conditions, it was possible to modulate the nature of the product, and several unprecedented compounds possessing extended structures have been isolated and characterized. In addition to these results, we also report a novel three-dimensional organotin sulfonate coordination polymer present in a honeycomb structure.
elements.clean_text: Accordingly, in this paper we report three-component reactions involving organotin oxides/disulfonic acids/N-oxides or P-oxides. Depending on the type of N-oxide or P-oxide ligand as well as the reaction conditions, it was possible to modulate the nature of the product, and several unprecedented compounds possessing extended structures have been isolated and characterized. In addition to these results, we also report a novel three-dimensional organotin sulfonate coordination polymer present in a honeycomb structure.

elements.content: As described above, a 1:2 reaction of [n-Bu2SnO] n with 2,5-xylyldisulfonic acid dihydrate afforded the tetraaqua diorganotin cation [n-Bu2Sn(H2O)4][2,5-Me2-C6H3SO3]2. This reaction is quite general and can be replicated with other sulfonic acids also. Thus, we were able to isolate and characterize, by 119Sn NMR, the compound [n-Bu2Sn(H2O)4][C10H6-1,5-(SO3)2] (I). Attempts to crystallize this compound allowed the isolation of a reorganized product [(H2O)3 n-Bu2Sn(μ-C10H6-1,5-(SO3)2)n-Bu2Sn(H2O)3][C10H6-1,5-(SO3)2] (II, Scheme a), containing one of the disulfonates as a bridging ligand between the two tin centers while the other disulfonate remains as a counteranion (here the Sn/disulfonic acid stoichiometry is 1:1; note the difference when the Sn/disulfonic acid ratio is 2:1, as discussed vide infra). Compound II was earlier obtained by us by a Sn−C bond cleavage reaction and, hence, is not described here. We were interested in exploring the reaction of [n-Bu2SnO] n with 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid, as earlier reports and work from our own lab indicated that the reaction product is strongly dependent on the stoichiometry of the reagent, with the tetraaqua compound being formed exclusively in the 1:1 reaction. Accordingly, we found that if the reaction is carried out in a 2:1 stoichiometry, [{n-Bu2Sn(μ-OH)}2{1,5-C10H6(SO3)2}] n (1) (Scheme b) is formed predominantly. 1 is an unprecedented 3D-coordination polymer and is the first example of a 3D-framework solid containing exclusively the organotin sulfonate motifs. Among organotin compounds, which have been structurally characterized, only three examples are known to date, containing an organodisulfonate as the primary ligand. In comparison to organotin carboxylates, -phosphinates, and -phosphonates, organotin sulfonates have been less well-studied, although notably through the work of Ward and co-workers, the utility of sulfonates in forming hydrogen-bonded supramolecular structures is now known.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthetic Aspects

As described above, a 1:2 reaction of [n-Bu2SnO] n  with 2,5-xylyldisulfonic acid dihydrate afforded the tetraaqua diorganotin cation [n-Bu2Sn(H2O)4][2,5-Me2-C6H3SO3]2. This reaction is quite general and can be replicated with other sulfonic acids also. Thus, we were able to isolate and characterize, by 119Sn NMR, the compound [n-Bu2Sn(H2O)4][C10H6-1,5-(SO3)2] (I). Attempts to crystallize this compound allowed the isolation of a reorganized product [(H2O)3 n-Bu2Sn(μ-C10H6-1,5-(SO3)2)n-Bu2Sn(H2O)3][C10H6-1,5-(SO3)2] (II, Scheme a), containing one of the disulfonates as a bridging ligand between the two tin centers while the other disulfonate remains as a counteranion (here the Sn/disulfonic acid stoichiometry is 1:1; note the difference when the Sn/disulfonic acid ratio is 2:1, as discussed vide infra). Compound II was earlier obtained by us by a Sn-C bond cleavage reaction and, hence, is not described here. We were interested in exploring the reaction of [n-Bu2SnO] n  with 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid, as earlier reports and work from our own lab indicated that the reaction product is strongly dependent on the stoichiometry of the reagent, with the tetraaqua compound being formed exclusively in the 1:1 reaction. Accordingly, we found that if the reaction is carried out in a 2:1 stoichiometry, [{n-Bu2Sn(μ-OH)}2{1,5-C10H6(SO3)2}] n  (1) (Scheme b) is formed predominantly. 1 is an unprecedented 3D-coordination polymer and is the first example of a 3D-framework solid containing exclusively the organotin sulfonate motifs. Among organotin compounds, which have been structurally characterized, only three examples are known to date, containing an organodisulfonate as the primary ligand. In comparison to organotin carboxylates, -phosphinates, and -phosphonates, organotin sulfonates have been less well-studied, although notably through the work of Ward and co-workers, the utility of sulfonates in forming hydrogen-bonded supramolecular structures is now known.

elements.content: Learning lessons from our previous attempts at preparing supramolecular structures from [n-Bu2Sn(H2O)4][2,5-Me2-C6H3SO3]2, we decided to modify our strategy. We decided not to isolate the tetraaqua species but only to form it in situ and use it as such. In all the cases, recrystallization of the products was carried out using acidic conditions (see ) to minimize deprotonation reactions. Also, we decided to employ the difunctional 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid, realizing the stabilizing influence of its anion on the eventual structures through its coordinating/hydrogen-bonding capabilities. The second modification consisted in using bifunctional N-oxide and P-oxide ligands. In one case, we used a mixed N-oxide/carboxylate as the ligand. The advantage of these ligands is to exploit the well-known oxophilicity of Sn(IV). In addition, these ligands were expected to be less of Brønsted bases (and hence would not lead to oxide formation) and more of nucleophilic ligands that would enable substitution of the aqua ligands around the organotin center. To a large extent, as described below, these expectations were realized and it was possible to systematically prepare compounds possessing organotin nodes in 1D−3D structures in the solid-state.

elements.content: A reaction between [n-Bu2SnO] n and 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid tertrahydrate followed by the reaction of the in situ formed [n-Bu2Sn(H2O)4][1,5-C10H6(SO3)2] (I) with 2 equiv of the bifunctional N-oxide BPDO-II (a flexible coordinating ligand) afforded [n-Bu2Sn(H2O)2(BPDO-II)2][1,5-C10H6(SO3)2] (2) (Scheme a). 2 is a discrete species which has a 3D-supramolecular structure as a result of a multitude of intermolecular hydrogen-bonding interactions (see below).

elements.content: Reaction of I with 1 equiv of BPDO-II results in a coordination polymer [n-Bu2Sn(μ-BPDO-II){μ-1,5-C10H6(SO3)2}] n (3) (Scheme b). In this coordination polymer, successive diorganotin units are bridged by one BPDO-II and one disulfonate ligand, respectively. We believe that reaction of I with 1 equiv of BPDO-II forces the involvement of both the N-oxide functions in coordination to the tin center, accompanied by the approach of disulfonate ligand toward tin, leading to the formation of 3, unlike 2. Isolation of the latter, containing two monocoordinated BPDO-II, was made possible by using 2 equiv of the ligand.
elements.clean_text: Reaction of I with 1 equiv of BPDO-II results in a coordination polymer [n-Bu2Sn(μ-BPDO-II){μ-1,5-C10H6(SO3)2}] n  (3) (Scheme b). In this coordination polymer, successive diorganotin units are bridged by one BPDO-II and one disulfonate ligand, respectively. We believe that reaction of I with 1 equiv of BPDO-II forces the involvement of both the N-oxide functions in coordination to the tin center, accompanied by the approach of disulfonate ligand toward tin, leading to the formation of 3, unlike 2. Isolation of the latter, containing two monocoordinated BPDO-II, was made possible by using 2 equiv of the ligand.

elements.content: The reaction of I with the difunctional phosphine oxide ligand DPPOE, irrespective of the Sn/DPPOE stoichiometry of 1:1 and 1:2, resulted in the formation of the coordination polymer [n-Bu2Sn(μ-DPPOE)(μ-1,5-C10H6(SO3)2)] n (4) (Scheme c). The macrocyclic polymeric structure of 4 is similar to that found in 3 and is a result of the bridging coordination action of DPPOE as well as the disulfonate ligand. Interestingly, we have recently reported organotin-based macrocyclic coordination polymeric networks by the reaction of diorganotin dihalides with pyrazole-3,5-dicarboxylic acid.
elements.clean_text: The reaction of I with the difunctional phosphine oxide ligand DPPOE, irrespective of the Sn/DPPOE stoichiometry of 1:1 and 1:2, resulted in the formation of the coordination polymer [n-Bu2Sn(μ-DPPOE)(μ-1,5-C10H6(SO3)2)] n  (4) (Scheme c). The macrocyclic polymeric structure of 4 is similar to that found in 3 and is a result of the bridging coordination action of DPPOE as well as the disulfonate ligand. Interestingly, we have recently reported organotin-based macrocyclic coordination polymeric networks by the reaction of diorganotin dihalides with pyrazole-3,5-dicarboxylic acid.

elements.content: In order to understand the effect of the substituents on tin on the final product formation, we carried out a 1:1 reaction between [Ph2SnO] n and 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid tetrahydrate, and the in situ formed [Ph2Sn(H2O)4][1,5-C10H6(SO3)2] was reacted with 1 equiv of BPDO-II, affording [{Ph2Sn(μ-BPDO-II)(H2O)2}{1,5-C10H6(SO3)2}·2H2O] n (5·2H2O) (Scheme d). The structure of 5 consists of the exclusive bridging coordination action of BPDO-II ligands, while the sulfonate ligands remain outside the coordination sphere. Carrying out this reaction under other stoichiometric conditions resulted in insoluble polymeric products.
elements.clean_text: In order to understand the effect of the substituents on tin on the final product formation, we carried out a 1:1 reaction between [Ph2SnO] n  and 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid tetrahydrate, and the in situ formed [Ph2Sn(H2O)4][1,5-C10H6(SO3)2] was reacted with 1 equiv of BPDO-II, affording [{Ph2Sn(μ-BPDO-II)(H2O)2}{1,5-C10H6(SO3)2}⋅2H2O] n  (5⋅2H2O) (Scheme d). The structure of 5 consists of the exclusive bridging coordination action of BPDO-II ligands, while the sulfonate ligands remain outside the coordination sphere. Carrying out this reaction under other stoichiometric conditions resulted in insoluble polymeric products.

elements.content: The trimethylene spacer connecting the two pyridine N-oxide units in BPDO-III was expected to provide greater flexibility to the bridging ligand and afford products containing larger free space. Accordingly, the reaction of I with BPDO-III in a 1:2 stoichiometry afforded [{n-Bu2Sn(μ-BPDO-III)2}{1,5-C10H6(SO3)2}·5H2O] n (6·5H2O) (Scheme a). A slight variation of the reaction conditions (see ) resulted in the isolation of [{n-Bu2Sn(BPDO-III-H)2(μ-1,5-C10H6(SO3)2)}{1,5-C10H6(SO3)2}] n (7) (Scheme b). Briefly, the addition of BPDO-III to a reaction mixture of [n-Bu2SnO] n and 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid tetrahydrate was immediately followed by workup to obtain crystals of 6·5H2O. In the preparation of 7, BPDO-III was added after 2 h and the reaction mixture was allowed to stir further for 2 days before workup. In contrast to the case for 6, in 7 one of the N-oxide groups of BPDO-III is protonated and, hence, only one end of it is coordinated to tin. On the other hand, as a result of this modified coordination behavior of BPDO-III, the disulfonate ligand is drawn into the coordination sphere of tin and acts to bridge successive tin units.
elements.clean_text: The trimethylene spacer connecting the two pyridine N-oxide units in BPDO-III was expected to provide greater flexibility to the bridging ligand and afford products containing larger free space. Accordingly, the reaction of I with BPDO-III in a 1:2 stoichiometry afforded [{n-Bu2Sn(μ-BPDO-III)2}{1,5-C10H6(SO3)2}⋅5H2O] n  (6⋅5H2O) (Scheme a). A slight variation of the reaction conditions (see ) resulted in the isolation of [{n-Bu2Sn(BPDO-III-H)2(μ-1,5-C10H6(SO3)2)}{1,5-C10H6(SO3)2}] n  (7) (Scheme b). Briefly, the addition of BPDO-III to a reaction mixture of [n-Bu2SnO] n  and 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid tetrahydrate was immediately followed by workup to obtain crystals of 6⋅5H2O. In the preparation of 7, BPDO-III was added after 2 h and the reaction mixture was allowed to stir further for 2 days before workup. In contrast to the case for 6, in 7 one of the N-oxide groups of BPDO-III is protonated and, hence, only one end of it is coordinated to tin. On the other hand, as a result of this modified coordination behavior of BPDO-III, the disulfonate ligand is drawn into the coordination sphere of tin and acts to bridge successive tin units.

elements.content: We have mentioned previously that the 2:1 reaction of [n-Bu2SnO] n with 1,5-naphthalene disulfonic acid tetrahydrate afforded the 3D-coordination polymer 1. It was of interest to carry out this reaction in the presence of linking ligands without allowing the reaction to proceed toward 1. Accordingly, we carried out a 2:1:1 reaction between [n-Bu2SnO] n and 1,5-naphthalene disulfonic acid tetrahydrate in the presence of DPPOE which allowed the isolation of [{n-Bu2Sn(DPPOE)2}{μ-1,5-C10H6(SO3)2}2{n-Bu2Sn(CH3OH)(μ-OH)}2·2H2O] n (8·2H2O) (Scheme ). The formation of the [Sn2(μ-OH)2] unit is consistent with the product obtained in the reaction without the bridging ligand. The formation of 8 indicates that the intermediate product in the 2:1 reaction of [n-Bu2SnO] n with 1,5-naphtahlenedisulfonic contains the teraaquo organotin dication along with another species containing a [Sn2(μ-OH)2] unit. If this reaction is allowed to go to completion, in the absence of DPPOE, the 3D-coordination polymer 1 is obtained.

elements.content: We wished to investigate the nature of the product obtained in these reactions with a ligand containing both the N-oxide and carboxylate functional groups. Accordingly, a 2:1 reaction of [n-Bu2SnO] n with 1,5-naphthalene disulfonic acid tetrahydrate, followed by 2 equiv of NO-IV afforded two types of products depending on the crystallization conditions. Crystallization at a low (<15 °C) temperature yielded [(n-Bu2Sn)(μ-1,5-C5H4(NO)(COO))2(μ-1,5-C10H6(SO3)2)(n-Bu2Sn)(H2O)(CH3OH)·CH3OH] n (9·CH3OH, Scheme a) whereas crystallization at a relatively higher temperature (>20−25°) afforded [(n-Bu2Sn)(H2O)(μ-1,5-C5H4(NO)(COO)(μ-1,5-C10H6(SO3)2)1/2] n (10); see Scheme b. The solid-state IR spectra of these compounds revealed differences in the stretching frequencies corresponding to the bound water molecules. While 9·CH3OH showed a single broad peak at 3422 cm−1, in 10, this peak is split in two, appearing at 3319 cm−1 and 3208 cm−1, respectively. This indicates that the bound water molecule in the case of 10 is a terminal ligand and is not involved in strong intermolecular hydrogen bonding interactions. This proposition is supported from the X-ray crystal structure analysis of 10 as discussed vide infra. 9·CH3OH is a kinetically stable product, formed first in solution, which shrinks and transforms to 10 at higher temperature (>20−25°), after removal of the trapped solvent molecules. This behavior is consistent with that revealed by certain porous framework solids which undergo guest-induced structural change. Such 2D-frameworks showing dynamic behavior have been of interest in recent years.

elements.content: 119Sn NMR spectra for compounds 2−7 were recorded using (CD3)2SO as solvent. All these compounds were found to be partially soluble in DMSO-d 6 on warming the samples. The 119Sn spectrum of 2, 3, 4, 6·5H2O, and 7 displayed single peaks at −383.9, −381.4, −384.3, −383.1, and −381.6 ppm, respectively. These values suggest the presence of hexacoordinated tin species and are similar to the corresponding values reported for [n-Bu2Sn(H2O)4][C10H6-1,5-(SO3)2] (δ = −384.9 ppm) and [ n Bu2Sn(H2O)3(μ-1,5-C10H6-(SO3)2)(H2O)3Sn- n Bu2][1,5-(C10H6SO3)2](H2O)3Sn n Bu2][1,5-(C10H6SO3)2] (−385.7 ppm). 5·2H2O showed a single resonance at −506.5 ppm. Sparing solublility of 1 and 8·2H2O in (CD3)2SO precluded the observation of a resonance in its 119Sn NMR spectrum. Also, solutions of 9·CH3OH or 10 in (CD3)2SO did not display any 119Sn resonance, which may be attributed to the presence of more than one kind of species in equilibrium, whose rate of exchange is fast on the NMR time scale. The 31P NMR spectrum of 4 and 8·2H2O in (CD3)2SO solution revealed single peaks at 31.7 ppm and 30.9 ppm, respectively.

elements.content: The crystal structure of 1 shows that it is a three-dimensional coordination polymer. The repeat unit of this polymer is shown in Figure a, and its selected bond distances and bond angles are listed in Table . The repeat unit contains a four-membered distannoxane [Sn2(μ-OH)2] unit containing two symmetrically related tin centers, four n-butyl groups, and one 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate ligand. Each hexacoordinated (2C, 4O) tin atom exhibits a distorted octahedral geometry. The coordination environment around each tin center comprises two bridging hydroxide ligands (O1 and O1*), two 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate ligands (O2 and O4**), and two n-butyl substituents (C1 and C5). The Sn−O distances present in the four-membered [Sn2(μ-OH)2] unit are 2.092(6) Å and 2.114(6) Å. The Sn−O distances involving sulfonate coordination are 2.398(5) Å for Sn1−O4** and 2.500(7) Å for Sn1−O2. These may be compared to the Sn−Osulfonate distances found in [{n-Bu2Sn(μ-OH)(2,5-Me2-C6H3SO3)}2] n [2.341(2) and 2.624(2) Å ]. In general, the sulfonate ligand can bind to metal ions in various ways. These modes are summarized in Chart . The mode of binding in the present instance corresponds to type a. The Sn−O−Sn bond angle of the four-membered ring in 1 is 108.6(3)°, and the O−Sn−O angle is 71.4(3)°. The four-membered distannoxane [Sn2(μ-OH)2] units are linked to each other by an anisobidentate bridging action of the 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate ligand, affording a three-dimensional coordination polymer. Views of this polymer parallel to the crystallographic b and c axes are provided in parts b and c, respectively, of Figure . Figure b shows a two-dimensional cross section of the 3D polymer. It reveals the presence of interlinked catenated [Sn2(μ-OH)2] units generating a grid like structure. The disulfonate coordination extends the coordination polymer into the third dimension, weaving it into an aesthetically appealing honeycomb pattern. The apparent voids within the honeycomb lattice are not really free but are occupied by the n-butyl groups present on the tin atoms. Although we and others have previously reported interesting organotin sulfonate 2D-structures, the present structure for 1 is completely unprecedented and is made possible only because of the coordination involvement of both the sulfonate groups present in the ligand. Catenated [Sn2(μ-OH)2] units are also quite rare among organostannoxanes. Previously we reported the molecular compound [n-BuSn(OH)L]6·3H2O·2CHCl3 (LH2 = 9-hydroxy-9-fluorenecarboxylic acid), where three [Sn2(μ-OH)2] groups were stitched together by the multiple coordination action of L.

elements.content: The molecular structure of 2 is depicted in Figure a, and its selected bond parameters are provided in Table . 2 is a discrete dicationic complex. The coordination (2C, 4O) around the central tin atom (Sn1) comprises two BPDO-II ligands (O1 and O1*), two coordinated water molecules (O6 and O6*), and two “n-butyl” substituents (C1 and C1*). Various coordination modes are known for BPDO-II (Chart ), and the mode of binding observed in the current instance is of type a. The Sn−O distances involving BPDO-II and a water molecule are not too different: 2.267(3) Å (Sn1−O1) and 2.242(3) Å (Sn−O6), respectively. The Sn−Ow distances involving the Sn−H2O units are comparable to that found in other instances: [{n-Bu2Sn(Ph3PO)2(H2O)2}{CF3SO3}2] (average Sn−Ow 2.237(3) Å), II (average Sn−Ow = 2.203 Å), [{n-Bu2Sn(H2O)4}{2,5-Me2-C6H3SO3}2] (average Sn−Ow 2.271(3) Å). The aromatic rings of BPDO-II are twisted by 32.5° with respect to each other. The presence of two N-oxide end-groups and two coordinated water molecules sets the stage for the generation of an interesting supramolecular structure in 2. The free, terminal oxygen atoms (O2 and O2*) of the two BPDO-II ligands form strong hydrogen bonds with one of the hydrogen atoms [(H6B) (O−H···O = 1.927(5)) Å], of the coordinated water of an adjacent molecule, leading to the formation of a one-dimensional chain comprising 26-membered hydrogen bonded rings (Figure b). Subsequent secondary O···π, O−H···O, and C−H···O interactions take this structure into a 2D-chain sheet [Figure S3(a) of the ]. These 2D-sheets are associated with each other through strong C−H···O interactions that occur between one of the oxygen atoms of the disulfonate unit of one layer and two hydrogen atoms, one each from BPDO-II and the naphthyl moiety of disulfonate, belonging to the adjoining layer, affording a 3D-supramolecular structure [Figure S3(b) of the ].

elements.content: The crystal structure of 3 unfolds the presence of a two-dimensional coordination polymer (Figure ). Selected bond distances and angles of 3 are provided in Table . The 2D-sheet of 3 is built from the interlinking of near square-grids (12.58 Å × 11.55 Å). The four corners of the square-grid are occupied by di-n-butyltin node. The grid itself is made up of a 40-membered Sn4S4N4O8C20 macrocycle (considering the contiguous 4-atom short connecting part of each naphthalene unit and the contiguous 6-carbon atom short connecting unit of the BPDO-II unit). The formation of this square-grid geometry in 3 is satisfying, as it confirms our belief that organotin motifs can be designed and used to form supramolecular structures of definite architectures.

Each of the tin atoms contained in the 2D-polymer is present in an octahedral coordination environment (2C, 4O) comprising two trans BPDO-II ligands, two trans 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate ligands (O2 and O2*), and two trans n-butyl groups. The average Sn−OBPDO-II bond distance (those involving BPDO-II ligation) is 2.223(3) Å, while the Sn−Osulfonate bond distance is 2.247(3) Å. It is interesting to note that, unlike in 2, in the case of 3, BPDO-II ligands do not exhibit any torsion; that is, both the aromatic rings of BPDO-II are in the same plane. Individual 2D-sheets of 3 are stacked together to afford a three-dimensional assembly [Figure S5(a) of the ], mediated by C−H···O hydrogen bonding interactions between the hydrogen atoms of BPDO-II of one sheet and one of the free oxygen atoms of the 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate ligand of the adjacent layer. The cavity present parallel to the crystallographic c axis is occupied by n-butyl groups coordinated to the tin center [Figure S5(b) of the ].

elements.content: Similar to 3, the crystal structure of 4 also revealed a 2D-coordination polymer. The repeat unit of the polymer 4 contains one tin, two n-butyl groups, one DPPOE, and one 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate ligand. Selected bond parameters of 4 are given in Table . Each tin atom is octahedrally (2C, 4O) coordinated to two trans DPPOE ligands (O1 and O1* for Sn1, O5 and O5* for Sn2), two trans 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate units (O2 and O2* for Sn1, O6 and O6* for Sn2), and two trans butyl groups. The two-dimensional sheet of 4, as shown in Figure , is composed of 32-membered Sn4P4S4O8C12 macrocylic units. The Sn····Sn separation indicates the presence of nanodimensional near square grids (10.98 Å × 9.20 Å). It is interesting to note that the grid dimensions in 3 are larger (12.58 Å × 11.55 Å) in comparison to that found in 4. The average Sn−ODPPOE bond distance (those involving DPPOE ligation) is 2.207 Å (Sn1−O1 2.212(4) Å; Sn2−O5 2.202(5) Å), while the average Sn−Osulfonate bond distance of 2.216 Å is comparable with that found for 3 (2.247(3) Å). The space between the corrugated layers of the supramolecular structure of 4 is filled with phenyl groups attached to the phosphorus atom of the DPPOE ligand (Figure S7 of the ). Weak C−H···O contacts between the adjacent layers bring them together into a three-dimensional structure (Figure S7 of the ).

elements.content: The crystal structure of 5·2H2O reveals the presence of a cationic one-dimensional coordination polymer (Figure a). The repeat unit of the 1D-polymer of 5 contains one tin atom, two phenyl groups, one BPDO-II, and one 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate ligand. Selected bond distances and bond angles for 5·2H2O are given in Table . The coordination environment around each octahedral (4O, 2C) tin center comprises two trans BPDO-II ligands (O3 and O3* for Sn1, O4 and O4* for Sn2), two coordinated water molecules (O1 and O1* for Sn1, O2 and O2* for Sn2), and two phenyl groups. The trans angles involved (180°) are indicative of a perfect octahedral geometry at each tin center. In this case, the bond involving the BPDO-II ligand and the tin center is shorter (Sn1−O3 2.187(3) and Sn2−O4 2.188(4) Å, Table ) and, hence, stronger as compared to those observed for 2 (2.267 Å), as discussed vide supra. The Sn−Ow distances are also slightly shorter in this case (2.219(4) Å) (for 2, Sn−Ow = 2.242 Å). As illustrated in Figure a, there exists strong hydrogen bonding interactions between bonded water molecules and anionic 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate ligands, which slightly differ at the crystallographically independent Sn1 and Sn2. For Sn1, the hydrogen atoms of the coordinated water molecules (O1 and O1*) are directly hydrogen-bonded to the sulfonate oxygens (O5 and O8), while for Sn2 the coordinated water (O2 and O2*) is in hydrogen bonding interactions with the lattice water molecules (O11 and O12) (represented by “light blue” spheres), which are in turn H-bonded to the oxygen atoms (O6, O7, O9, and O10) of the disulfonate anion. The metric parameters involved are given in Table S7 of the . The above interactions glue together two 1D-polymeric chains, leading to the formation of a 2D-layer (along the crystallographic ac plane; Figure S9(a) of the ). These interactions also propagate in the direction perpendicular to this 2-D sheet (along b axis), giving rise to a 3D-hydrogen-bonded architecture, which unfolds channels filled with solvent (water, O11, and O12) molecules (Figure b). The basic H-bonding motif of the 3D-structure of 5·2H2O, showing the interchain interactions, is shown in the [Figure S9(b)].

Crystal structure analysis reveals that 6·5H2O is a cationic one-dimensional coordination polymer (Figure a), whose repeat unit, based on the asymmetric unit composition, consists of one tin, two n-butyl groups, and two BPDO-III ligands (see also Figure S10 of the ). The positive charges on the polymeric chain are balanced by the presence of one 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate anion per tin unit. Selected bond distances and bond angles are provided in Table . Each hexacoordinated (2C, 4O) tin center is surrounded by four BPDO-III ligands (O1, O1*, O2, and O2*) and two trans n-butyl groups. As shown in Figure a, two consecutive tin atoms in a particular 1D-chain are linked by the bridging action of two BPDO-III ligands, thereby generating a 28-membered Sn2O4N4C18 macrocycle. Thus, this 1D-polymer is a double chain polymer. Adjacent macrocyclic rings (shown as R1 and R2 in Figure a) are oriented perpendicular to each other, creating a twisted figure eight configuration. The Sn−O distances involving BPDO-III ligands are Sn1−O1 2.221(3) Å and Sn1−O2 2.210(3) Å. Thus, while the average Sn−OBPDO-III distance (2.215 Å) is comparable to the Sn−OBPDO-II distance in the 2D-polymer 3 (2.223(3) Å), it is shorter and stronger than the corresponding distance found in discrete cation 2 [2.267(3) Å]. Adjoining chains are associated with each other through two sets of π···π interactions [labeled as P1 (N1 C5−C9, N1 C5−C9; 3.614(6) Å) and P2 (C18−C22, N2 C13−C17); 3.648(9) Å, Figure a], involving aromatic rings of 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate anions and those of BPDO-III ligands of adjacent chains. Interaction among these chains is further strengthened by a O···π contact (3.382(3) Å) between an oxygen atom (O2) of one of the pyridine-N-oxide moieties of the BPDO-III ligand and the aromatic rings of 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate anions. These interactions lead to the formation of a 2D-assembly (Figure a, and Figure S11 of the ). Also, there are two and a half lattice water molecules (O6, O7, and O8) per asymmetric unit, which interact with the 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate anions through strong hydrogen bonding interactions. Figure b unfolds a zigzag arrangement of the chain of water molecules present in the crystal lattice. These interactions propagate in all three directions. The O···O distances involved in these interactions fall in the range 2.73−2.98 Å.

elements.content: Compound 7 also is a 1D-coordination polymer (Figure ). The repeat unit of the cationic polymer 7 contains one tin, two n-butyl groups, two monoprotonated BPDO-III, and one 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate ligand. The coordination environment around each of the octahedrally (2C, 4O) coordinated tin centers comprises two trans BPDO-III ligands (O1 and O1*), two trans 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate ligands (O2 and O2*), and two n-butyl groups. Selected bond lengths and bond angles of 7 are listed in Table . Unlike the case of 6·5H2O, formation of the 1D-chain in this case is accomplished by the coordinative bridging action of 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate ligands (Figure ). One out of the two N-oxide functionalities (N2−O2) of each of the bound BPDO-III ligands is free and protonated, and the resultant dipositive charge developed per repeat unit is balanced by the presence of one 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate anion. The protonated N-oxide moiety of BPDO-III ligands of a particular chain is engaged in forming a O···π interaction [3.343(5) Å], with the aromatic ring of the nonprotonated pyridine-N-oxide function of the BPDO-III ligand belonging to chains present below or above [Figure S13(a) of the ]. Simultaneously, one of the aromatic hydrogen atoms (H15) of the protonated pyridine-N-oxide motif of BPDO-III bound to one chain forms a strong C···H−O contact with the pyridine-N-oxide of BPDO-III originating from an adjacent chain. The metric parameters involved are C15···H15−O1 2.237(2) Å, 165.0(22)°. These interactions are responsible for stacking of cationic 1D-chains along the b axis. Propagation of the structure along the ac plane is mediated by O−H···O interactions, which is described as follows. There exists a strong hydrogen bond between one of the oxygen atoms (O6) of the disulfonate anions and a hydrogen atom (H51) of the protonated N-oxide function emerging from two nearby chains (O5−H51···O6 1.750(3) Å; 167.97(19)°) [Figure S13(b) of the ]. Moreover, a cartoon diagram given in Figure S13(c) of the illustrates the pattern followed by these hydrogen bonding interactions (between polymeric cationic chains and the disulfonate anion). It reveals that the consecutive terminal protonated N-oxide groups originating from one chain of a particular stack are linked to the corresponding groups of different chains of an adjacent stack. The outcome is an interlocking of contiguous chains via anionic 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonates, into a three-dimensional network (Figure S14 of the ). Such networks are extremely unusual among organotin compounds.

The crystal structure of 8·2H2O reveals it to be a one-dimensional polymer, which contains two types of organotin motifs alternating with each other and bridged by the disulfonate ligand (Figure a). While one of these motifs comprises a discrete diorganotin center (Sn1) containing two bonded DPPOE ligands, with the latter being coordinated in a trans fashion, the other contains a hydroxide-bridged dinuclear tin motif (Sn2 and Sn2*). Selected bond parameters for 8·2H2O are provided in Table . The octahedral coordination (2C, 4O) around Sn1 is completed by two DPPOE ligands (O1 and O1*), two bridging 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate ligands (O3 and O3*), and trans n-butyl groups (C1 and C1*). The Sn−O distance involving DPPOE is 2.237(4) Å and is slightly longer than the Sn−ODPPOE bond distance found in 4 (2.207 Å), as discussed vide supra. The Sn−O distance involving disulfonate coordination at Sn1 is 2.241(5) Å, which is also a little longer than the average Sn−Osulfonate distance found in 4 (2.216 Å). Unlike mononuclear Sn1, Sn2 is a part of symmetric dimeric [Sn2(μ-OH)2] motif. Weaker coordination of disulfonate to Sn2, compared to that for Sn1, is characterized by a longer Sn−O bond distance of 2.429(5) Å. However, it is comparable with the average Sn−Osulfonate bond distance found in 1 (2.449 Å), as discussed vide supra. The distorted octahedral coordination environment (4O, 2C) around Sn2 comprises one 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate ligand (O6), two bridging hydroxides (O9 and O9*), one weakly coordinated methanol and two n-butyl groups. The oxygen atom of the coordinated methanol (at Sn2) is disordered over two positions (O10A and O10B) [Sn−O10A 2.488(2) Å, Sn−O10B 2.429(5) Å]. The hydrogen atom (H101) of the bridging hydroxide group of [Sn2(μ-OH)2] motif of one chain forms a strong O−H···O contact [O2···O9 2.664(8) Å] with the free terminal “PO” motif (O2) of the DPPOE ligand coordinated to the Sn1 located on an adjoining chain. These interactions generate a two-dimensional H-bonded layer across the crystallographic bc plane (Figure b). The grid patterns of this hydrogen-bonded structure are differently formed from those observed in 3 and 4. Alternate corners of these grids contain tin centers derived from the discrete unit and the [Sn2(μ-OH)2] motif, respectively. The lattice guest water molecules interact with the coordinated methanol molecules and the sulfonate oxygens, further enriching the supramolecular structure (Figure S16; ).

X-ray Crystal Structure of [{n-Bu2Sn(DPPOE)2}{μ-1,5-C10H6(SO3)2}2{n-Bu2Sn(CH3OH)(μ-OH)}2⋅2H2O] n  (8⋅2H2O)

The crystal structure of 8⋅2H2O reveals it to be a one-dimensional polymer, which contains two types of organotin motifs alternating with each other and bridged by the disulfonate ligand (Figure a). While one of these motifs comprises a discrete diorganotin center (Sn1) containing two bonded DPPOE ligands, with the latter being coordinated in a trans fashion, the other contains a hydroxide-bridged dinuclear tin motif (Sn2 and Sn2*). Selected bond parameters for 8⋅2H2O are provided in Table . The octahedral coordination (2C, 4O) around Sn1 is completed by two DPPOE ligands (O1 and O1*), two bridging 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate ligands (O3 and O3*), and trans n-butyl groups (C1 and C1*). The Sn-O distance involving DPPOE is 2.237(4) Å and is slightly longer than the Sn-ODPPOE bond distance found in 4 (2.207 Å), as discussed vide supra. The Sn-O distance involving disulfonate coordination at Sn1 is 2.241(5) Å, which is also a little longer than the average Sn-Osulfonate distance found in 4 (2.216 Å). Unlike mononuclear Sn1, Sn2 is a part of symmetric dimeric [Sn2(μ-OH)2] motif. Weaker coordination of disulfonate to Sn2, compared to that for Sn1, is characterized by a longer Sn-O bond distance of 2.429(5) Å. However, it is comparable with the average Sn-Osulfonate bond distance found in 1 (2.449 Å), as discussed vide supra. The distorted octahedral coordination environment (4O, 2C) around Sn2 comprises one 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate ligand (O6), two bridging hydroxides (O9 and O9*), one weakly coordinated methanol and two n-butyl groups. The oxygen atom of the coordinated methanol (at Sn2) is disordered over two positions (O10A and O10B) [Sn-O10A 2.488(2) Å, Sn-O10B 2.429(5) Å]. The hydrogen atom (H101) of the bridging hydroxide group of [Sn2(μ-OH)2] motif of one chain forms a strong O-H⋅⋅⋅O contact [O2⋅⋅⋅O9 2.664(8) Å] with the free terminal "PO" motif (O2) of the DPPOE ligand coordinated to the Sn1 located on an adjoining chain. These interactions generate a two-dimensional H-bonded layer across the crystallographic bc plane (Figure b). The grid patterns of this hydrogen-bonded structure are differently formed from those observed in 3 and 4. Alternate corners of these grids contain tin centers derived from the discrete unit and the [Sn2(μ-OH)2] motif, respectively. The lattice guest water molecules interact with the coordinated methanol molecules and the sulfonate oxygens, further enriching the supramolecular structure (Figure S16; ).

elements.content: The crystal structure of 9·CH3OH reveals a 2D-coordination polymer, repeat unit of which shows the presence of two types of tin centers exhibiting different types of coordination environment. Parts a and b of Figure depict the coordination environment around Sn1 and Sn2, respectively. Sn1 is coordinated to two trans n-butyl groups (C1 and C5), two carboxylate moieties (O1 and O12) of two bonded NO-IV ligands, and one coordinated water molecule (O13). In contrast, Sn2 is enveloped by two trans 1,5-naphthalendisulfonate groups (O4 and O7), two N-oxide functionalities (O3 and O10) of two trans NO-IV ligands, and trans n-butyl groups (C15 and C19) (Figure b). Selected bond parameters for 9·3CH3OH are summarized in Table . The bond distances involving the coordination of the carboxylate moiety of NO-IV to Sn1 are 2.251(4) Å (Sn1−O1) and 2.228(4) Å (Sn1−O12). One of the carboxylate ligands exhibits an anisobidentate coordination mode (Sn1−O12, 2.228(4) Å and Sn1−O11, 2.781(7) Å). A strong water coordination is identified by a short bond distance of 2.111(5) Å (Sn1−O13). Out of the two methanol molecules found in the vicinity of Sn1, one interacts with Sn1 to form a weak Sn−O bond of 2.611(6) Å. Thus, the resultant geometry around Sn1 can be considered as distorted pentagonal bipyramidal. The trans angles involved at Sn2 are C15−Sn2−C19 179.3(2)°, O3−Sn2−O10 179.40(15)°, and O4−Sn2−O7 177.55(15)°, which point to a near perfect octahedral geometry at tin. The Sn−O bond lengths involving the N-oxide functionality of NO-IV are Sn2−O3 2.202(4) Å and Sn2−O10 2.229(5) Å, while those characterizing the disulfonate coordination are Sn2−O4 2.279(4) Å and Sn2−O7 2.298(4). Thus, the average Sn2−ON-oxide bond distance (2.215 Å) is less than the average Sn2−Osulfonate distance of 2.288 Å, indicating a slightly stronger binding of NO-IV than the disulfonate ligand.

9·CH3OH as viewed across the crystallographic ab plane reveals it to be a 2D-coordination polymer containing two types of macrocyclic building units (Figure c). Although both the units comprise 46-membered Sn6S4O12N4C20 rings, one of them contains free methanol molecules (C39, O14). On the other hand, methanol (O15, C40) molecules in the other macrocyclic cavity appear to be weakly interacting with the tin center (Sn1; 2.611(6) Å). Based on the Sn2···Sn2 separation, two similar types of rectangular grids (15.92 Å × 10.14 Å; 15.92 Å × 9.99 Å) can be identified in the 2D-coordination polymer [Figure S18(a) of the ]. The connectivity between Sn1 and Sn2 can be given as follows; each Sn1 is connected to two Sn2 units (Sn2 and Sn2′) through bridging NO-IV, while each Sn2 is linked to two Sn1 (Sn1 and Sn1′) through bridging NO-IV and two other Sn2 (Sn2′′ and Sn2′′′) centers involving the 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate ligand as the bridging motif. As shown in (Figure c), guest methanol molecules (C39, O14) are held in the channels present parallel to the crystallographic c axis and are sustained by strong hydrogen bonding interactions with a coordinated water molecule (O13) and a nonbonding oxygen atom (O8) of one of the sulfonate groups of the bridging 1,5-naphthalendisulfonate ligand. The O···O distances involved in these interactions are O13···O14 2.553(1) Å and O14···O8 2.713(9) Å (Table S9 of the ). A space-filling diagram of 9, after omission of guest methanol molecules (C39, O14) is given in Figure S18c of the . It unfolds the presence of channels parallel to the c axis, of approximate dimension 11.8 Å × 6.2 Å. Consecutive 2D-sheets of 9·CH3OH are associated with each other with the help of weak C−H···O contacts [Figure S18(b) of the ].

elements.content: The crystal structure of 10 reveals it to be a neutral 2D-coordination polymer (Figure ). The coordination environment around the tin center is depicted in Figure a, and selected bond parameters are listed in Table . Interestingly, in the octahedrally coordinated (2C, 4O) tin center in the repeat unit of 10, all four oxygen atoms belong to four different functionalities: O5, O2, O4, and O1 derived from 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate, the carboxylate function of NO-IV, the N-oxide functionality of NO-IV, and the coordinated water molecule respectively. The Sn−O distance involving the N-oxide group (Sn1−O4) is 2.191(2) Å, which is slightly shorter than the average Sn−O N-oxide distance found in 9·2CH3OH (2.215 Å). The Sn−O bond lengths characterizing the coordination of the carboxylate function of NO-IV and that of the disulfonate ligand are Sn1−O2 2.120(2) Å and Sn1−O5 2.421(2) Å, respectively. Thus, while the Sn−O bonds involving N-oxide (Sn1−O4) and carboxylate (Sn1−O2) functionalities are of comparable strength, those involving the disulfonate ligand (Sn1−O5) are relatively weak. At the same time, the average Sn−Osulfonate distance is also longer than that in 9·CH3OH (average Sn−Osulfonate = 2.288 Å). A view of the neutral two-dimensional coordination polymer of 10, parallel to the bc plane, is provided in Figure b. As illustrated in this figure, each tin atom in the 2D-sheet is connected to the three crystallographically related tin centers (Sn′, Sn′′, Sn′′′) by the bridging action of NO-IV (with Sn′ and Sn′′) or 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate (with Sn′′′). Also, it becomes evident that this 2D-layer is made up of 46-membered Sn6S4O12N4C20 macrocyclic subunits. The mutual orientation of macrocyclic subunits reveals an interesting herringbone packing, whereby adjacent subunits are present nearly perpendicular to each other, affording a “V” shaped arrangement. These 2D-layers are taken into the third dimension with the aid of further noncovalent interactions (Figure S20 of the ). The space between adjacent layers is occupied by n-butyl groups.

Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out for complexes 1−10, in order to investigate their thermal stability (see Figures S21−S30 of the ). The TGA curve of 3D-polymer 1 (Figure S21) shows an average decomposition temperature of 327 °C. The TGA curve of 2 (Figure S22) displayed an initial weight loss of 10.6% at ∼190 °C, corresponding to a gradual loss of water molecules (theoretical loss, 11.6%). In contrast to 2, 3 is stable until ∼325 °C (Figure S23). Although 3 and 4 possess a similar coordination framework (2D polymer), 4 showed a relatively lower thermodynamic stability than 3 and revealed an initial weight loss of 3.22% in the temperature range ∼260−315 °C (Figure S24) which may be attributed to the loss of an oxygen molecule (2O, calcd: 3.37%). The thermal analysis data for 5·2H2O is provided in Figure S25. It becomes evident from the TGA curve that both the noncoordinated and coordinated water molecules are lost before ∼160 °C, accounting for a weight drop of ∼8.4% (calcd: 8.8%), eventually affording a residue which is apparently stable until the onset of the next major mass loss at ∼320 °C. This is in contrast to the behavior shown by 2 (where removal of bonded water molecules was soon followed by decomposition). Heating a sample of 6·5H2O resulted in a preliminary weight loss of 8.5% corresponding to the removal of lattice water molecules (calcd, 8.9%) until 150 °C (Figure S26). The resultant solid is stable until ∼200 °C. Compound 7 witnessed decomposition at ∼250 °C (Figure S27). Thus, 7 is relatively more robust than 6·5H2O. The Thermogravimetric curve of 8·2H2O () unveiled a similarity in degradation pattern with that of 4, although the latter is relatively more robust. An initial drop of ∼3.6% below 85 °C may be attributed to the loss of adsorbed and lattice water molecules, which followed a gradual loss of coordinated solvent (methanol) molecules beyond 100 °C. The average decomposition temperature for this compound is 353 °C. Heating a sample of 9·CH3OH () until ∼165 °C removed all the lattice and coordinated methanol molecules and half of the bound water molecules (obsd 6.6%, calcd 6.6%). The resultant residue is apparently stable until ∼225 °C, where decomposition was initiated. Thermal data of 10 () displayed a 3.54% decline in weight in the temperature range 105−165 °C due to the loss of bound water molecules (calcd, 3.54%); further decomposition begins only at ∼225−230 °C. Thus, all the organostannoxane-based assemblies described herein show a reasonable level of thermal stability, which may be useful in evaluating their potential utility.

elements.content: Hydrated diorganotin cations can be used as effective precursors for the preparation of a variety of novel compounds. By using appropriate bi-/polyfunctional ligands, it is possible to prepare compounds that span a wide range, from molecular solids to 3D-solids. Significantly, most of these assemblies are prepared under ambient reaction conditions. An important aspect of the preparation of the hydrated diorganotin cations is the dependence of the product on the diorganotin/sulfonic acid stoichiometry. Thus, in reactions where the stoichiometry is kept at 1:2 (in this case, since we used a disulfonic acid, the stoichiometry of the diorganotin oxide/disulfonic acid ratio was kept at 1:1) to generate the diorganotin tetra-aqua compound [n-Bu2Sn(H2O)4][1,5-C10H6(SO3)2] (I). The tendency of the hydrated species to undergo condensation reactions affording hydroxide/oxide bridged solids can be curbed by using acidic conditions which inhibit deprotonation reactions. On the other hand, it is possible to modulate the product formation in the diorganotinoxide/sulfonic acid reactions. The reaction can be steered to afford a product containing [Sn2(μ-OH)2] units by either doing the reaction at a diorganotin/sulfonic acid ratio of 1:1 (in the present case 2:1 because of the use of disulfonic acid) or by allowing the reaction to afford condensed products. The latter can be done by simply reducing the acidity of the reaction condition; even use of mild bases affords such products. Thus, by utilizing appropriate reaction conditions, we have assembled [{n-Bu2Sn(μ-OH)}2{1,5-C10H6(SO3)2}] n (1), the first example of an organotin 3D-coordination polymer containing exclusively sulfonate ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Hydrated diorganotin cations can be used as effective precursors for the preparation of a variety of novel compounds. By using appropriate bi-/polyfunctional ligands, it is possible to prepare compounds that span a wide range, from molecular solids to 3D-solids. Significantly, most of these assemblies are prepared under ambient reaction conditions. An important aspect of the preparation of the hydrated diorganotin cations is the dependence of the product on the diorganotin/sulfonic acid stoichiometry. Thus, in reactions where the stoichiometry is kept at 1:2 (in this case, since we used a disulfonic acid, the stoichiometry of the diorganotin oxide/disulfonic acid ratio was kept at 1:1) to generate the diorganotin tetra-aqua compound [n-Bu2Sn(H2O)4][1,5-C10H6(SO3)2] (I). The tendency of the hydrated species to undergo condensation reactions affording hydroxide/oxide bridged solids can be curbed by using acidic conditions which inhibit deprotonation reactions. On the other hand, it is possible to modulate the product formation in the diorganotinoxide/sulfonic acid reactions. The reaction can be steered to afford a product containing [Sn2(μ-OH)2] units by either doing the reaction at a diorganotin/sulfonic acid ratio of 1:1 (in the present case 2:1 because of the use of disulfonic acid) or by allowing the reaction to afford condensed products. The latter can be done by simply reducing the acidity of the reaction condition; even use of mild bases affords such products. Thus, by utilizing appropriate reaction conditions, we have assembled [{n-Bu2Sn(μ-OH)}2{1,5-C10H6(SO3)2}] n  (1), the first example of an organotin 3D-coordination polymer containing exclusively sulfonate ligands.

elements.content: The reactions between [n-Bu2Sn(H2O)4][1,5-C10H6(SO3)2] (I) and difunctional N-oxide/P-oxide or multifunctional N-oxide-carboxylate ligands have yielded rich dividends, and a number of polymeric solids featuring one-dimensional chains and two-dimensional sheets as basic motifs (which eventually extend to the third dimension, mediated by strong noncovalent interactions) have been isolated. All of these represent a new class of organotin compounds exhibiting structural diversity, which have been realized by following a stepwise approach of generation of diorganotin cation under controlled hydrolytic conditions preceding their treatment with various rigid and flexible ditopic N-oxide or P-oxide ligands. These ligands, owing to their less basic nature, favor coordination over hydrolysis at the cationic diorganotin center. The Sn/L (L = bifunctional coligand) stoichiometric ratio can be used to steer the course of the reaction, including playing a decisive role in allowing access to the sulfonate anion to coordinate to tin. The formation of molecular [{n-Bu2Sn(BPDO-II)2(H2O)2}{1,5-C10H6(SO3)2}] (2) and a 2D-coordination polymer [n-Bu2Sn(μ-BPDO-II)(μ-1,5-C10H6(SO3)2)] n (3) was achieved by using Sn/BPDO-II ratios of 1:2 and 1:1, respectively. The formation of [{Ph2Sn(μ-BPDO-II)(H2O)2}{1,5-C10H6(SO3 −)2}·2H2O] n (5·2H2O) also demonstrates another subtle effect in allowing sulfonate coordination. Thus, the presence of phenyl substituents on tin appears to force the sulfonates out of the coordination environment of tin. However, more studies are needed where a systematic variation of the sulfonate coordination is effected to test this hypothesis. The isolation of [n-Bu2Sn(μ-DPPOE)(μ-1,5-C10H6(SO3)2)] n (4), which is nearly isostructural with 3, reveals that under similar reactions merely changing the bifunctional ligand from N-oxide to P-oxide does not change the structure of the products. This is comforting from the design point of view, as it reveals the potential of the three-component reactions, presented in this work, to afford 2D-coordination frameworks of predictable structures. These structures also indicate the possibility of tuning the cavity size by changing the length of the rigid bifunctional neutral spacer, as well as the disulfonate motif.

elements.content: Increasing the flexibility of the bridging ligand (BPDO-III) allowed the isolation of the 1D chain [{n-Bu2Sn(μ-BPDO-III)2}{1,5-C10H6(SO3 −)2}·5H2O] n (6·5H2O). A slight change of reaction conditions allows the protonation of one side of BPDO-III and therefore prevents this part of the ligand from interacting with the tin. Modulating the initial reaction conditions in the three-component strategy allowed the isolation of [{n-Bu2Sn(DPPOE)2}{μ-1,5-C10H6(SO3)2}2{n-Bu2Sn(CH3OH)(μ-OH)}2·2H2O] n (8·2H2O). The latter represents a unique case where the initially formed hydrated organotin cation part and its condensed form are in the same product, validating the belief that the latter are derived from the former in a sequential reaction.

A slight change of reaction conditions allows the protonation of one side of BPDO-III and therefore prevents this part of the ligand from interacting with the tin. Modulating the initial reaction conditions in the three-component strategy allowed the isolation of [{n-Bu2Sn(DPPOE)2}{μ-1,5-C10H6(SO3)2}2{n-Bu2Sn(CH3OH)(μ-OH)}2⋅2H2O] n  (8⋅2H2O). The latter represents a unique case where the initially formed hydrated organotin cation part and its condensed form are in the same product, validating the belief that the latter are derived from the former in a sequential reaction.

elements.content: The coordination polymers [(n-Bu2Sn)(μ-1,5-C5H4(NO)(COO))2(μ-1,5-C10H6(SO3)2)(n-Bu2Sn)(H2O)}·CH3OH] n (9·CH3OH) and [(n-Bu2Sn)(H2O){μ-1,5-C5H4(NO)(COO)}{μ-1,5-C10H6(SO3)2}1/2] n (10) are obtained by a variation of crystallization conditions in the three component reactions using the N-oxide-carboxylate NO-IV as the bridging ligand. The multiple coordination action of NO-IV allows the isolation of these compounds which have unique structures.

The multiple coordination action of NO-IV allows the isolation of these compounds which have unique structures.

elements.content: To conclude, we have demonstrated the efficacy of the three-component organotinoxide/sulfonic acid/bridging ligand reactions in generating a wide-range of compounds whose structures vary from being purely molecular to extended solids. The understanding from this study should allow us to design new thermally stable porous 3D-solids using organotin motifs. The presence of Lewis-acidic tin as part of such frameworks should render them to interesting applications, including catalysis. These studies are in progress.

elements.content: Solvents were distilled and dried prior to use, according to standard procedures. [n-Bu2SnO] n , [Ph2SnO] n , 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid tetrahydrate, 4,4′-bipyridine, 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane, nicotinic acid, 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)ethane (all from Aldrich), glacial acetic acid, 98% H2SO4 (sd fine, India), and 30% hydrogen peroxide (Rankem, India) were purchased and used without any further purification. 4,4′-Bipyridine-N,N′-dioxide dihydrate (BPDO-II), 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane-N,N′-dioxde dihydrate (BPDO-III), nicotinic acid N-oxide (NO-IV), and 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphoryl)ethane (DPPOE) were prepared by literature methods. A 0.1 N H2SO4 (pH = 1.33) solution was made in double distilled water to be used for the maintainence of acidic pH during crystallization. Melting points were measured using a JSGW melting point apparatus and are uncorrected. Elemental analyses were carried out using a Thermoquest CE instruments model EA/110 CHNS-O elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded as KBr pellets on a FT-IR Bruker-Vector Model. 1H, 31P, and 119Sn NMR spectra were obtained on a JEOL-DELTA2 500 model spectrometer using (CD3)2SO as solvent. Chemical shifts were referenced with respect to tetramethylsilane (for 1H NMR), 80% H3PO4 (31P), and tetramethyltin (for 119Sn NMR), respectively. 119Sn NMR spectra were recorded under broad-band decoupled conditions. Thermogravimetric analysis was carried out on a Perkin-Elmer Pyris 6 thermogravimetric analyzer.

Experimental Section

Solvents were distilled and dried prior to use, according to standard procedures. [n-Bu2SnO] n , [Ph2SnO] n , 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid tetrahydrate, 4,4'-bipyridine, 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane, nicotinic acid, 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)ethane (all from Aldrich), glacial acetic acid, 98% H2SO4 (sd fine, India), and 30% hydrogen peroxide (Rankem, India) were purchased and used without any further purification. 4,4'-Bipyridine-N,N'-dioxide dihydrate (BPDO-II), 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane-N,N'-dioxde dihydrate (BPDO-III), nicotinic acid N-oxide (NO-IV), and 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphoryl)ethane (DPPOE) were prepared by literature methods. A 0.1 N H2SO4 (pH = 1.33) solution was made in double distilled water to be used for the maintainence of acidic pH during crystallization. Melting points were measured using a JSGW melting point apparatus and are uncorrected. Elemental analyses were carried out using a Thermoquest CE instruments model EA/110 CHNS-O elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded as KBr pellets on a FT-IR Bruker-Vector Model. 1H, 31P, and 119Sn NMR spectra were obtained on a JEOL-DELTA2 500 model spectrometer using (CD3)2SO as solvent. Chemical shifts were referenced with respect to tetramethylsilane (for 1H NMR), 80% H3PO4 (31P), and tetramethyltin (for 119Sn NMR), respectively. 119Sn NMR spectra were recorded under broad-band decoupled conditions. Thermogravimetric analysis was carried out on a Perkin-Elmer Pyris 6 thermogravimetric analyzer.

elements.content: A mixture of [n-Bu2SnO] n (0.20 g, 0.80 mmol) and 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid tetrahydrate (0.15 g, 0.40 mmol) was stirred in a mixture of toluene and methanol (24 mL, 5:3) for 24 h at room temperature. The white precipitate obtained was filtered and washed with 2 mL each of methanol, acetone, and diethyl ether and then subsequently dried in open air. The crystal data for compounds 1−10 were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractrometer. The SMART software package (version 5.628) was used for collecting data frames, the SAINT software package (version 6.45) was used for integration of the intensity and scaling, and SADABS was used for absorption correction. The details pertaining to the data collection and refinement for crystals are provided in Tables S1−S4 of the . The structures were solved and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL software package. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms were included in idealized positions, and a riding model was used. In the case of 1 ( of the ), three carbons of the tin bound n-butyl group are doubly disordered (C6 and C6A; C7 and C7A; C8 and C8A). The highest residual electron density of 2.70 is located near the tin atom. For 3 (), three carbon atoms of the n-butyl group were found to have orientational disorder and were refined isotropically. These are labeled as C2 and C2A; C3 and C3A; C4 and C4A. The highest residual electron density of 1.42 is located near Sn1. In the asymmetric unit of 4 (), four carbon atoms, two from each of the two n-butyl groups present, are doubly disordered (C3 and C3A; C4 and C4A (for Sn1) and C6 and C6A; C8 and C8A (for Sn2)) and were refined isotropically. Because of the large anisotropic displacement parameters, some of the carbon atoms (C20, C21, C40) of phosphorus bound phenyls were refined isotropically. The highest residual electron density of 1.73, situated near C39, may be attributed to the unresolved disorder associated with this atom, which in turn was refined isotropically. The asymmetric unit of 5·2H2O () contains two lattice water molecules (O11 and O12). While the hydrogens (H55 and H56) were located from the difference Fourier map and added to one of the lattice water molecules (O11), due to diffused electron density around O12, hydrogens could not be located from the difference Fourier map and have not been added to it. In the asymmetric unit of 6·5H2O (), due to diffused electron density, hydrogens were not added to the oxygen atom of the lattice water molecules and these have been refined isotropically. The terminal carbon atom of the n-butyl group is doubly disordered (C4 and C4A) and was refined isotropically. In the case of 8·2H2O (), the oxygen atom of the methanol molecule bound to Sn2 is disordered over two positions, labeled as O10 A and O10 B. Similarly, the oxygen atom of the lattice water molecule has orientational disorder (O11 A and O11 B). The positions of these oxygens have been refined isotropically. Hydrogens have not been added to these oxygen atoms. In the asymmetric unit of 9·CH3OH (), it was difficult to locate the hydrogens around the oxygen atom (O13) of bound water and the oxygen atom (O14) of one of the methanol molecules, because of diffused electron density around these atoms. The highest residual electron density in this case is 6.04 and is situated near one of the tin atoms (Sn1). Structures 1−10 and their bonding parameters were obtained from the DIAMOND 3.1f software package.
