A mixture of [n-Bu2SnO] n (0.20 g, 0.80 mmol) and 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid tetrahydrate (0.15 g, 0.40 mmol) was stirred in a mixture of toluene and methanol (24 mL, 5:3) for 24 h at room temperature. The white precipitate obtained was filtered and washed with 2 mL each of methanol, acetone, and diethyl ether and then subsequently dried in open air. Its solution in a mixture of methanol and a few drops of acidified water afforded blocklike colorless crystals of 1. Yield: 0.18 g (56%). Mp: > 250 °C. Anal. Calcd for C26H44O8S2Sn2 (788.1 g) (%): C, 39.59; H, 5.63. Found: C, 39.81; H, 5.73. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3474 [ν(OH)]; 1197 [s, ν(SO3) asymm str]; 1034 [s, ν(SO3) sym str]; 603 [m, ν(C−S) str]. 1H NMR (500 MHz, (CD3)2SO): δ = 8.73 (d, b, 2H, naphthyl-CH), 7.81 (d, b, 2H, naphthyl-CH), 7.32 (d, b, 2H, naphthyl-CH), 0.71−0.83 (m, 12H, CH 3), 1.15−1.48 (m, 24H, SnCH 2CH 2CH 2).

[{<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>-Bu<sub>2</sub>Sn(BPDO-II)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>}{1,5-C<sub>10</sub>H<sub>6</sub>(SO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>}] (<bold>2</bold>)

A mixture of [n-Bu2SnO] n (0.124 g, 0.50 mmol) and 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid tetrahydrate (0.187 g, 0.52 mmol) was stirred in a mixture of toluene and methanol (16 mL, 5:3) for 3 h at room temperature. A white precipitate was obtained. To the reaction mixture was added 2 equiv of BPDO-II (0.22 g, 1.00 mmol). The reaction mixture was further stirred for 36 h to afford a white precipitate, which was filtered off, washed with 2 mL each of methanol, acetone, and diethyl ether, and then dried in open air. Its solution in a mixture of methanol and a few drops of acidified water afforded blocklike crystals of 2 suitable for single crystal X-ray analysis. Yield: 0.28 g (61%). Mp: >250 °C. Anal. Calcd for C38H44N4O12S2Sn (932.2 g) (%): C, 48.92; H, 4.76; N, 6.01. Found: C, 49.01; H, 4.83; N, 6.18. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3399 [br, ν(H2O)]; 1210 [s, ν(SO3) asymm str]; 1176 [s, ν(SO3) asymm str]; 1032 [s, ν(SO3) ionic sym str]; 608 [m, ν(C−S) str]; 1249(s), 1226(vs), 805(s), 766(m), 703(w), 552(m) [BPDO-II]. 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d 6): δ = 7.34 (m, 2H, naphthyl-CH), 7.53−7.94 (m, 2H, naphthyl-CH, and 4H, BPDO-II-CH), 8.24−8.62 (m, 4H, BPDO-II-CH), 8.82 (d, 2H, naphthyl-CH), 0.80−0.94 (m, 6H, CH 3), 1.15−1.22 (m, 4H, SnCH 2), 1.44 (m, 8H, CH 2CH 2). 119Sn NMR (500 MHz, (CD3)2SO): δ = −383.9(s).

[<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>-Bu<sub>2</sub>Sn(μ-BPDO-II)(μ-1,5-C<sub>10</sub>H<sub>6</sub>(SO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

A mixture of [n-Bu2SnO] n (0.11 g, 0.44 mmol) and 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid tetrahydrate (0.16 g, 0.44 mmol) was taken in a mixture of toluene/methanol (16 mL, 5:3), and the contents were stirred at room temperature for 3.5 h, affording a white precipitate. Subsequently, BPDO-II (0.10 g, 0.44 mmol) was added and the stirring continued for 36 h. The precipitated solid was washed with methanol, acetone, and diethyl ether and recrystallized from a mixture of methanol and acidified water. Yield: 0.23 g (74%). Mp: >270 °C. Anal. Calcd for C28H32N2O8S2Sn (708.06 g) (%): C, 47.45; N, 3.95; H, 4.55. Found: C, 47.95; N, 4.01; H, 4.7. IR (KBr, cm−1): 1147, 1179 [s, ν(SO3) asymm str], 608 [s, ν(C−S)], 3108(m), 1474(s), 1378(m), 833(s), 804(m), 704(m), 552(s) [BPDO-II]. 1H NMR (500 MHz, (CD3)2SO): δ = 8.82 (d, 2H, naphthyl-CH), 7.92 (d, 2H, naphthyl-CH), 7.41 (d, 2H, naphthyl-CH), 7.85 (dd, 4H, BPDO-II-CH), 8.26 (dd, 4H, BPDO-II-CH), 0.83 (t, 6H, Sn−CH 3), 123−1.27 (m, 4H, SnCH 2), 1.42−1.50 (m, 8H, CH 2CH 2). 119Sn NMR (500 MHz, (CD3)2SO): δ = −381.4 ppm (s).

[<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>-Bu<sub>2</sub>Sn(μ-DPPOE)(μ-1,5-C<sub>10</sub>H<sub>6</sub>(SO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

A mixture of [n-Bu2SnO] n (0.07 g, 0.30 mmol) and 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid tetrahydrate (0.11 g 0.30 mmol) was taken in a mixture of toluene/methanol (16 mL, 5:3), and the reaction contents were stirred at room temperature for 15 min, followed by addition of DPPOE (0.13 g, 0.30 mmol). The reaction mixture was allowed to react for 3 days. The white precipitate obtained was washed with methanol and diethyl ether and rerystallized from a mixture of methanol and acidified water to afford 4 . Yield: 0.17 g (63%). Mp: 250 °C (decomp). Anal. Calcd for C44H48O8P2S2Sn (949.57 g): C, 55.57; H, 5.09. Found: C, 56.10; H, 4.65. IR (KBr, cm−1): 1270, 1170 [s, ν(SO3) asymm str]; 607 [s, ν(C−S)]; 1187(s), 1146(vs) [ν(PO)]; 531(s), 505(s), 414(w) [ν(P-Ph)]. 1H NMR (500 MHz, (CD3)2SO): δ = 7.12−7.55 (m, 20H, DPPOE-CH), 1.48−1.50 (m, 4H, DPPOE-CH 2 ), 7.69−7.73 (dd, 2H, naphthyl-CH), 7.90−7.92 (d, 2H, naphthyl-CH), 8.80−8.82 (d, 2H, naphthyl-CH), 0.83 (t, 6H, Sn−CH 3), 1.23−1.43 (m, 12H, Sn−CH 2 CH 2CH 2 ). 31P NMR (500 MHz, (CD3)2SO): δ = 31.7 ppm (s). 119Sn NMR (500 MHz, (CD3)2SO): δ = −384.3 ppm (s).

[{Ph<sub>2</sub>Sn(μ-BPDO-II)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>}{1,5-C<sub>10</sub>H<sub>6</sub>(SO<sub>3</sub> <sup>−</sup>)<sub>2</sub>}·2H<sub>2</sub>O]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>5</bold>·2H<sub>2</sub>O)

A suspension of [n-Ph2SnO] n (0.12 g, 0.40 mmol) and 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid tetrahydrate (0.15 g, 0.42 mmol) was stirred in a mixture of toluene and methanol (24 mL, 5:3) for 3 h. A white precipitate was obtained. To the reaction mixture was added BPDO-II (0.094 g, 0.42 mmol). The contents were further stirred for 36 h to afford a white precipitate, which was filtered, washed with methanol, acetone, and diethyl ether, and dried in open air. The solution of this solid in methanol/DMF/acidified water afforded blocklike crystals of 5·2H2O suitable for single crystal X-ray analysis. Yield: 0.13 g (40%). Mp: >250 °C (dec). Anal. Calcd for C32H42N2O12S2Sn (819.41) (%): C, 46.26; H, 5.10; N, 3.37. Found: C, 46.40; H, 5.29; N, 3.40. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3398 [s br, ν(H2O)]; 1220 [s, ν(SO3) asymm str]; 1158 [m, ν(SO3) asymm str]; 1034 [s, ν(SO3) sym str]; 608 [m, ν(C−S) str]; 3111(b,m), 3079(b,m), 1242(s), 1187(s), 557(m), 457(w) [BPDO-II]. 1H NMR (500 MHz, (CD3)2SO): δ = 7.35−7.38 (t, 2H, naphthyl-CH), 8.82 (d, 2H, naphthyl-CH), 7.74−7.89 (m, 2H, naphthyl-CH, and 4H, BPDO-II-CH), 8.32 (d, 4H, BPDO-II-CH), 7.43−7.48 (m, 10H, SnC6 H 5 ). 119Sn NMR (500 MHz, (CD3)2SO): δ = −506.0(s).

[{<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>-Bu<sub>2</sub>Sn(μ-BPDO-III)<sub>2</sub>}{1,5-C<sub>10</sub>H<sub>6</sub>(SO<sub>3</sub> <sup>−</sup>)<sub>2</sub>}·5H<sub>2</sub>O]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>6</bold>·5H<sub>2</sub>O)

To a solution of 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid tetrahydrate (0.15 g 0.40 mmol) in 8 mL of toluene/methanol (5:3) was added [n-Bu2SnO] n (0.10 g, 0.40 mmol), and the mixture was allowed to stir at room temperature for 2 days, affording a white precipitate. Solvent was evaporated in vacuo, and the residue obtained was washed with 1 mL of methanol and diethyl ether. Addition of 10 mL of fresh methanol (8 mL) to this residue, followed by introduction of 2 equiv of BPDO-III (0.22 g, 0.80 mmoL), was accompanied by stirring. Immediately, a spherical solid lump separated out. This was followed by addition of a few drops of acidified water to the mixture. The contents were shaken for 10 min to dissolve the solid, filtered, and kept for slow evaporation at room temperature. Crystals of 6·5H2O were obtained after a few weeks. Yield: 0.33 g (52%). Mp: 160 °C. Anal. Calcd for C44H57N4O15S2Sn (1065.23 g) (%): C, 49.57; N, 5.26; H, 5.39. Found: C, 50.03; H, 5.09; N, 5.90. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3451 [br, ν(H2O)]; 1182 [s, ν(SO3) asymm str]; 1204 [s, ν(SO3) asymm str]; 1030 [s, ν(SO3) ionic sym str]; 609 [ν(C−S)]; 1489(ms), 1451(m), 843(m), 765(m) (BPDO-III). 1H NMR (500 MHz, (CD3)2SO): δ = 1.81−1.83 (m, 4H, BPDO-III-CH2CH 2 CH2), 2.56−2.59 (m, 8H, BPDO-III-CH 2 CH2CH 2 ), 7.29−7.31 (d, 8H, BPDO-III-CH), 8.15−8.16 (m, 8H, BPDO-III-CH), 7.91−7.92 (d, 2H, naphthyl-CH), 8.82−8.83 (d, 2H, naphthyl-CH), 7.39−7.42 (m, 2H, naphthyl-CH), 0.83 (t, 6H, Sn-CH 3), 1.22−1.26 (m, 12H, Sn-CH2), 1.41−1.48 (m, CH 2CH 2). 119Sn NMR (500 MHz, (CD3)2SO): δ = −383.1 ppm (s).

[{<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>-Bu<sub>2</sub>Sn(BPDO-III-H<sup>+</sup>)<sub>2</sub>}{μ-1,5-C<sub>10</sub>H<sub>6</sub>(SO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>}{1,5-C<sub>10</sub>H<sub>6</sub>(SO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>}]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>7</bold>)

To a solution of 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid tetrahydrate (0.22 g, 0.60 mmol) in 16 mL of toluene/methanol (5:3) was added [n-Bu2SnO] n (0.15 g, 0.60 mmol), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2 h, affording a white precipitate. This was followed by addition of 2 equiv of BPDO-III (0.32 g, 1.20 mmol), affording a lump of cream-colored solid preceding precipitation. The reaction contents were allowed to react further at room temperature over a period of 2 days. The precipitate that was formed was filtered and washed with methanol and diethyl ether. The solid obtained was dissolved in a methanol/acidified water mixture and kept for slow evaporation to afford crystals of 7 suitable for single crystal X-ray crystallography. Yield: 0.62 g (55%). Mp: 180 °C. Anal. Calcd for C54H60N4O16S4Sn (1268.19 g) (%): C, 51.10; H, 4.77; N, 4.42. Found: C, 51.53; H, 5.03; N, 4.89. IR (KBr, cm−1): 1211 [m, ν(SO3) asymm str], 1172 [s, ν(SO3) asymm str], 1005 [s, ν(SO3) sym str], 606 [s, ν(C−S)]; 1493(m), 1454(m), 845(m), 805(s), 758(w) [BPDO-III]. 1H NMR (500 MHz, (CD3)2SO): δ = 1.84−1.90 (m, 4H, BPDO-III-CH2CH 2 CH2), 2.63−2.66 (m, 8H, BPDO-III-CH 2 CH2CH 2 ), 7.48 (d, 8H, BPDO-III-CH), 8.39 (d, 8H, BPDO-III-CH), 7.89−7.91 (m, 4H, naphthyl-CH), 8.82 (d, 2H, naphthyl-CH), 0.82 (t, 6H, Sn-CH 3), 1.22−1.26 (m, 12H, Sn−CH 2), 1.41−1.50 (m, CH 2CH 2). 119Sn NMR (500 MHz, (CD3)2SO): δ = −381.6 (s).

[{<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>-Bu<sub>2</sub>Sn(DPPOE)<sub>2</sub>}{μ-1,5-C<sub>10</sub>H<sub>6</sub>(SO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>}<sub>2</sub>{<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>-Bu<sub>2</sub>Sn(CH<sub>3</sub>OH)(μ-OH)}<sub>2</sub>·2H<sub>2</sub>O]<sub>n</sub> (<bold>8</bold>·2H<sub>2</sub>O)

A mixture of [n-Bu2SnO] n (0.15 g, 0.60 mmol) and 1,5-naphthalendisulfonic acid tetrahydrate (0.11 g 0.30 mmol) was taken in a mixture of toluene/methanol (8 mL, 5:3), and the contents were stirred at room temperature for 20 min, affording a white precipitate. Subsequently, DPPOE (0.13 g, 0.30 mmol) was added and the reaction mixture was stirred for 4 days. The white solid obtained was washed with methanol and diethyl ether and recrystallized from a mixture of methanol and acidified water. Yield: 0.26 g (58%). Mp: > 260 °C. Anal. Calcd for C98H128O22P4S4Sn3 (2268.38 g) (%): C, 51.84; H, 5.69. Found: C, 52.16; H, 5.68. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3422 [br, ν(H2O)]; 1267, 1169 [s, ν(SO3) asymm str]; 1189(s), 1150(vs) [ν(PO)]; 532(s), 508(m), 419(w) [ν(P-Ph)]. 1H NMR (500 MHz, (CD3)2SO): δ = 7.45−7.54 (m, 12H, DPPOE-CH), 7.71−7.72 (m, br 8H, DPPOE-CH), 2.36 (s, 4H, DPPOE-CH 2 CH 2), 7.91 (d, 2H, naphthyl-CH), 8.82 (d, 2H, naphthyl-CH), 7.38−7.41 (m, naphthyl-CH), 0.82−0.85 (m, 12H, CH 3), 1.15−1.43 (m, 8H, Sn-CH 2), 1.48−1.55 (m, 16H, CH 2CH 2). 31P NMR (500 MHz, (CD3)2SO): δ = 30.9 ppm (s).

[{(<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>-Bu<sub>2</sub>Sn)(μ-1,5-C<sub>5</sub>H<sub>4</sub>(NO)(COO))<sub>2</sub>(μ-1,5-C<sub>10</sub>H<sub>6</sub>(SO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>)(<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>-Bu<sub>2</sub>Sn)(H<sub>2</sub>O)(CH<sub>3</sub>OH)}·CH<sub>3</sub>OH]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>9</bold>·CH<sub>3</sub>OH) and [(<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>-Bu<sub>2</sub>Sn)(H<sub>2</sub>O)(μ-1,5-C<sub>5</sub>H<sub>4</sub>(NO)(COO)(μ-1,5-C<sub>10</sub>H<sub>6</sub>(SO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>)<sub>1/2</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>10</bold>)

To a solution of 1,5-naphthalendisulfonic acid tetrahydrate (0.12 g, 0.30 mmol) in 10 mL of methanol was added [n-Bu2SnO] n (0.15 g, 0.6 mmol), and the suspension was stirred at room temperature for 15 min followed by addition of 1 equiv of NO-IV (0.10 g, 0.60 mmoL). The mixture was allowed to react for 3 days at room temperature. The white precipitate obtained was filtered and then washed with methanol and diethyl ether prior to its recrystallization from methanol/acidified water to afford 9·CH3OH and 10 at low (<15 °C) and higher temperature (>20−25 °C), respectively. Both the crystals differed significantly in their habits. While 9·CH3OH grew in the form of big cuboidal blocks, crystals of 10 developed as an aggregate of thick needles.

cln_elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out for complexes 1−10, in order to investigate their thermal stability (see Figures S21−S30 of the ). The TGA curve of 3D-polymer 1 (Figure S21) shows an average decomposition temperature of 327 °C. The TGA curve of 2 (Figure S22) displayed an initial weight loss of 10.6% at ∼190 °C, corresponding to a gradual loss of water molecules (theoretical loss, 11.6%). In contrast to 2, 3 is stable until ∼325 °C (Figure S23). Although 3 and 4 possess a similar coordination framework (2D polymer), 4 showed a relatively lower thermodynamic stability than 3 and revealed an initial weight loss of 3.22% in the temperature range ∼260−315 °C (Figure S24) which may be attributed to the loss of an oxygen molecule (2O, calcd: 3.37%). The thermal analysis data for 5·2H2O is provided in Figure S25. It becomes evident from the TGA curve that both the noncoordinated and coordinated water molecules are lost before ∼160 °C, accounting for a weight drop of ∼8.4% (calcd: 8.8%), eventually affording a residue which is apparently stable until the onset of the next major mass loss at ∼320 °C. This is in contrast to the behavior shown by 2 (where removal of bonded water molecules was soon followed by decomposition). Heating a sample of 6·5H2O resulted in a preliminary weight loss of 8.5% corresponding to the removal of lattice water molecules (calcd, 8.9%) until 150 °C (Figure S26). The resultant solid is stable until ∼200 °C. Compound 7 witnessed decomposition at ∼250 °C (Figure S27). Thus, 7 is relatively more robust than 6·5H2O. The Thermogravimetric curve of 8·2H2O () unveiled a similarity in degradation pattern with that of 4, although the latter is relatively more robust. An initial drop of ∼3.6% below 85 °C may be attributed to the loss of adsorbed and lattice water molecules, which followed a gradual loss of coordinated solvent (methanol) molecules beyond 100 °C. The average decomposition temperature for this compound is 353 °C. Heating a sample of 9·CH3OH () until ∼165 °C removed all the lattice and coordinated methanol molecules and half of the bound water molecules (obsd 6.6%, calcd 6.6%). The resultant residue is apparently stable until ∼225 °C, where decomposition was initiated. Thermal data of 10 () displayed a 3.54% decline in weight in the temperature range 105−165 °C due to the loss of bound water molecules (calcd, 3.54%); further decomposition begins only at ∼225−230 °C. Thus, all the organostannoxane-based assemblies described herein show a reasonable level of thermal stability, which may be useful in evaluating their potential utility.

Thermal Properties of Compounds 2-10 

Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out for complexes 1-10, in order to investigate their thermal stability (see Figures S21-S30 of the ). The TGA curve of 3D-polymer 1 (Figure S21) shows an average decomposition temperature of 327 °C. The TGA curve of 2 (Figure S22) displayed an initial weight loss of 10.6% at ~190 °C, corresponding to a gradual loss of water molecules (theoretical loss, 11.6%). In contrast to 2, 3 is stable until ~325 °C (Figure S23). Although 3 and 4 possess a similar coordination framework (2D polymer), 4 showed a relatively lower thermodynamic stability than 3 and revealed an initial weight loss of 3.22% in the temperature range ~260-315 °C (Figure S24) which may be attributed to the loss of an oxygen molecule (2O, calcd: 3.37%). The thermal analysis data for 5⋅2H2O is provided in Figure S25. It becomes evident from the TGA curve that both the noncoordinated and coordinated water molecules are lost before ~160 °C, accounting for a weight drop of ~8.4% (calcd: 8.8%), eventually affording a residue which is apparently stable until the onset of the next major mass loss at ~320 °C. This is in contrast to the behavior shown by 2 (where removal of bonded water molecules was soon followed by decomposition). Heating a sample of 6⋅5H2O resulted in a preliminary weight loss of 8.5% corresponding to the removal of lattice water molecules (calcd, 8.9%) until 150 °C (Figure S26). The resultant solid is stable until ~200 °C. Compound 7 witnessed decomposition at ~250 °C (Figure S27). Thus, 7 is relatively more robust than 6⋅5H2O. The Thermogravimetric curve of 8⋅2H2O () unveiled a similarity in degradation pattern with that of 4, although the latter is relatively more robust. An initial drop of ~3.6% below 85 °C may be attributed to the loss of adsorbed and lattice water molecules, which followed a gradual loss of coordinated solvent (methanol) molecules beyond 100 °C. The average decomposition temperature for this compound is 353 °C. Heating a sample of 9⋅CH3OH () until ~165 °C removed all the lattice and coordinated methanol molecules and half of the bound water molecules (obsd 6.6%, calcd 6.6%). The resultant residue is apparently stable until ~225 °C, where decomposition was initiated. Thermal data of 10 () displayed a 3.54% decline in weight in the temperature range 105-165 °C due to the loss of bound water molecules (calcd, 3.54%); further decomposition begins only at ~225-230 °C. Thus, all the organostannoxane-based assemblies described herein show a reasonable level of thermal stability, which may be useful in evaluating their potential utility.

cln_elements.content: (a) One dimensional coordination polymer of 5·2H2O, showing the difference in the hydrogen bonding pattern at Sn1 and Sn2 between coordinated water and 1,5-napthalenedisulfonate anion (Sn1 and Sn2 are crystallographically independent; however, there is symmetry, which explains that the occupancy in the crystal lattice is 0.5). (b) 3D-framework of 5·2H2O. Tin bound “phenyl” groups and hydrogen atoms (except hydrogens belonging to coordinated water molecules) have been omitted for the sake of clarity. The guest water molecules (O11 and O12) are shown as light blue balls.

(b) 3D-framework of 5⋅2H2O. Tin bound "phenyl" groups and hydrogen atoms (except hydrogens belonging to coordinated water molecules) have been omitted for the sake of clarity. cln_elements.content: (a) Association between adjoining 1D-chains of 6·5H2O is facilitated by the presence of 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate anions. Two types of π···π interactions are visible, labeled as P1 [π(N1, C5−C9)···π(N1, C5−C9), 3.614(6) Å)] and P2 [πcent(N2, C13−C17)···π cent(C18−C22), 3.648(9) Å]. O2···πcent(C18−C22), 3.382(3) Å. (b) Two-dimensional view along the ac plane, illustrating the zigzag arrangement of water molecules (shown as light blue spheres) held in the lattice. For metric parameters, see Table S8 of the Supporting Information. “n-Butyl” groups and hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity.

cln_elements.content: (a) 1D-polymer of 8·2H2O displaying both mono- (Sn1) and dimeric (Sn2) diorganotin motifs. The oxygen atom of methanol molecules (shown in the space-filling model) bound to the tin center (Sn2) is disordered over two positions (O10A and O10B, shown in light blue). (b) 2D-hydrogen bonded layer of 8·2H2O revealing near square grids of dimensions 11.478 Å × 11.323 Å, O9···O2 2.664(8)Å. “n-Butyl” groups, “phenyl” groups of DPPOE ligand, and all the hydrogen atoms except those of the hydroxide bridge have been omitted for clarity.
